00010 
00011 /* Version 1.1 */
00012 
00013 
00014 /*============================================================================ 
00015 ** On Intel Pentium processors (especially PIII and probably P4), converting
00016 ** from float to int is very slow. To meet the C specs, the code produced by 
00017 ** most C compilers targeting Pentium needs to change the FPU rounding mode 
00018 ** before the float to int conversion is performed. 
00019 **
00020 ** Changing the FPU rounding mode causes the FPU pipeline to be flushed. It 
00021 ** is this flushing of the pipeline which is so slow.
00022 **
00023 ** Fortunately the ISO C99 specifications define the functions lrint, lrintf,
00024 ** llrint and llrintf which fix this problem as a side effect. 
00025 **
00026 ** On Unix-like systems, the configure process should have detected the 
00027 ** presence of these functions. If they weren't found we have to replace them 
00028 ** here with a standard C cast.
00029 */
00030 
00031 /* 
00032 ** The C99 prototypes for lrint and lrintf are as follows:
00033 ** 
00034 **    long int lrintf (float x) ;
00035 **    long int lrint  (double x) ;
00036 */
00037 
00038 #include "Audacity.h"
00039 
00040 /* The presence of the required functions are detected during the configure
00041 ** process and the values HAVE_LRINT and HAVE_LRINTF are set accordingly in
00042 ** the config.h file.
00043 */
00044 
00045 #if (HAVE_LRINT && HAVE_LRINTF)
00046 
00047    /* These defines enable functionality introduced with the 1999 ISO C
00048    ** standard. They must be defined before the inclusion of math.h to
00049    ** engage them. If optimisation is enabled, these functions will be 
00050    ** inlined. With optimisation switched off, you have to link in the
00051    ** maths library using -lm.
00052    */
00053 
00054    #define  _ISOC9X_SOURCE 1
00055    #define  _ISOC99_SOURCE 1
00056 
00057    #define  __USE_ISOC9X   1
00058    #define  __USE_ISOC99   1
00059 
00060    #include <math.h>
00061    
00062 #elif (defined (WIN32) || defined (_WIN32))
00063 
00064    /* Win32 doesn't seem to have these functions. 
00065    ** Therefore implement inline versions of these functions here.
00066    */
00067    
00068    __inline long int 
00069    lrint (double flt)
00070    {  int intgr;
00071 
00072       _asm
00073       {  fld flt
00074          fistp intgr
00075          } ;
00076          
00077       return intgr ;
00078    } 
00079    
00080    __inline long int 
00081    lrintf (float flt)
00082    {  int intgr;
00083 
00084       _asm
00085       {  fld flt
00086          fistp intgr
00087          } ;
00088          
00089       return intgr ;
00090    }
00091 
00092    __inline long long int 
00093    llrint (double flt)
00094    {  long long int intgr;
00095 
00096       _asm
00097       {  fld flt
00098          fistp intgr
00099          } ;
00100          
00101       return intgr ;
00102    } 
00103    
00104    __inline long long int 
00105    llrintf (float flt)
00106    {  long long int intgr;
00107 
00108       _asm
00109       {  fld flt
00110          fistp intgr
00111          } ;
00112          
00113       return intgr ;
00114    }
00115 
00116 #else
00117 
00118    /* dmazzoni: modified these to do a proper rounding, even though
00119     * it's slower.  Correctness and consistency is more important
00120     * than speed, especially since lrint/lrintf are certainly not
00121     * available everywhere.
00122     *
00123     * MM: Now uses internal math.h rint() function
00124     */
00125 
00126    #include <math.h>
00127    
00128    #define  lrint(dbl)     ((int)rint(dbl))
00129    #define  lrintf(flt)    ((int)rint(flt))
00130 
00131 #endif
00132 
00133
